MWC.GenericData

Class WorldLocation

  • java.lang.Object
    • MWC.GenericData.WorldLocation
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    WorldLocation.LocalLocation

    public class WorldLocation
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    represents a 3-point in space, using World/Earth coordinates. Others classes also handle/maintain world coordinates.
    See Also:
    WorldArea, WorldVector, Serialized Form

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  WorldLocation.LocalLocation
      ******************************************************************* convenience class which allows a WorldLocation to be created using a world distance instead of a double for depth/heught *******************************************************************
      static class  WorldLocation.LocationTest

      • WorldLocation

        public WorldLocation(java.math.BigDecimal LatVal,
                     java.math.BigDecimal LongVal,
                     java.math.BigDecimal DepthVal)
        create a new location, in World coordinates. Added to support GPX.
        Parameters:
        LatVal - Latitude in degrees
        LongVal - Longitude in degrees
        DepthVal - Depth in metres

      • WorldLocation

        public WorldLocation(WorldLocation other)
        copy constructor
        Parameters:
        other - WorldLocation to copy

      • WorldLocation

        public WorldLocation(double latDegs,
                     double latMin,
                     double latSec,
                     char latHem,
                     double longDegs,
                     double longMin,
                     double longSec,
                     char longHem,
                     double theDepth)
        long winded constructor, taking raw arguments note: if there are decimal parts of degs or mins then the contents of the mins & secs, or secs (resp) are ignored. So, if there's 22.5 in the mins and 10 in the secs, this will go to 22 mins, 30 secs - using the mins fractional component and ignoring the secs value.
